This question is a long free-response question. Show your work for each part of the question.

A block of mass <math alttext="M"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is attached to a spring of negligible mass and can slide on a horizontal surface along the <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-direction, as shown above. There is friction present between the block and the surface. The spring exerts no force on the block when the center of the block is located at <math alttext="x equals 0"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. At the instant shown above, the block is located at <math alttext="x equals zero"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and moving toward the right with speed <math alttext="v equals v sub zero"><mstyle><mrow><mi>v</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(a) For the instant shown above, with the block located at <math alttext="x equals zero"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and moving to the right, predict the direction of the net force on the block. If the net force is zero, select “The net force is zero.”

____ To the left ____ The net force is zero ____ To the right

Briefly justify your prediction.

(b) The above graph indicates the force exerted on the block by the spring as a function of position <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, with the positive direction toward the right. On the same graph, draw a graph of the net force on the block, as a function of position <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, for situations where the block is moving toward the right.

(c) Is the graph you drew in part (b) consistent with your prediction in part (a) ?

____ Yes ____ No

Provide claims for why the answers to parts (a) and (b) are or are not consistent.

(d) In the figure above, the block of mass <math alttext="M"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> has come to rest at a location to the right of the spring’s equilibrium position. The spring has a spring constant <math alttext="k"><mstyle><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and the coefficients of kinetic and static friction between the block and the surface are <math alttext="mu sub k"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="mu sub s"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, respectively.

i. On the dot below, which represents the block at rest and to the right of <math alttext="x equals zero"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, draw and label the forces (not components) that act on the block. Each force must be represented by a distinct arrow starting on, and pointing away from, the dot.

ii. Derive an expression for the maximum displacement possible for the block that will allow the block to still remain at rest. Express your answer in terms of <math alttext="M"><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></math>, <math alttext="k"><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></math>, <math alttext="mu sub k"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></math>, <math alttext="mu sub s"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate.
